description: Python is a great language for learning, writing web applications, and manipulating data. However, Python can be used for security testing as well. In this series, we will explore the use of Python in such concepts as brute force password cracking, making SSH connections programmatically, creating socket connections and port scanner a particular host, banner grabbing from open ports, and more. If that sounds interesting to you, then please join us!

If that sounds interesting to you, then please join us!
name: Python for Security
subtitle: Being Sneaky with Python

episodes.description: Python is a great language for learning, writing web applications, and manipulating data. However, Python can be used for security testing as well. In this series, we will explore the use of Python in such concepts as brute force password cracking, making SSH connections programmatically, creating socket connections and port scanner a particular host, banner grabbing from open ports, and more. If that sounds interesting to you, then please join us!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.536
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.536 --> 00:00:09.001
In this segment we're gonna give you
a quick look at what you can expect from

3
00:00:09.001 --> 00:00:10.985
our upcoming Python for Security series.

4
00:00:10.985 --> 00:00:14.855
Justin, could you do us the immense favor
of giving us some of the topics that we're

5
00:00:14.855 --> 00:00:17.010
gonna encounter as refers to the series?

6
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:19.580
>> So there's a few things
that we're going to encounter.

7
00:00:19.580 --> 00:00:22.180
Most of what we're going to
be doing is network related,

8
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:26.220
because Python already has some
built in network related modules.

9
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:30.840
The socket library, create a server,
create a client, two set server.

10
00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:33.260
Also, maybe a little
bit of packet sniffing.

11
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:38.950
Moreover, we're gonna be looking at some
attacks to like various ports on your

12
00:00:38.950 --> 00:00:43.910
machine, various services, particularly
your brute force attack to the SSH client.

13
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:45.233
>> Very cool.

14
00:00:45.233 --> 00:00:51.040
We have a lot of different times that
we're doing certification based training.

15
00:00:51.040 --> 00:00:54.420
We also do technical skills
based training as well.

16
00:00:54.420 --> 00:00:57.310
Which one of those categories
would this series fall under?

17
00:00:57.310 --> 00:00:58.760
>> This is most definitely a tech skill.

18
00:00:58.760 --> 00:01:00.840
This is something where
a little bit of Python.

19
00:01:00.840 --> 00:01:02.470
I'm interested in security.

20
00:01:02.470 --> 00:01:04.360
How do those two come together?

21
00:01:04.360 --> 00:01:06.430
This is not certification based.

22
00:01:06.430 --> 00:01:08.530
It's more about, hey, I have this idea.

23
00:01:08.530 --> 00:01:11.650
Let me kind of make it come to
fruition in the context of security.

24
00:01:11.650 --> 00:01:12.810
>> And Justin, I always like to ask,

25
00:01:12.810 --> 00:01:15.720
who is the intended audience for
this series, as well?

26
00:01:15.720 --> 00:01:19.710
>> So the intended audience is, you should
probably have some experience with Python,

27
00:01:19.710 --> 00:01:22.710
cuz that's kind of
assumed from the outset.

28
00:01:22.710 --> 00:01:26.850
Otherwise, you're gonna be like,
I don't know what all of this is, right?

29
00:01:26.850 --> 00:01:29.020
So, some programming experience in Python,

30
00:01:29.020 --> 00:01:33.390
I'm not saying you have to be
an expert but you should have

31
00:01:33.390 --> 00:01:37.530
a basic understanding of variables,
lists, classes, so on and so forth.

32
00:01:37.530 --> 00:01:42.300
Moreover, you should have some basic
understanding of security principles, or

33
00:01:42.300 --> 00:01:49.280
at least attacks that can be employed
against a particular node or individual.

34
00:01:49.280 --> 00:01:52.100
>> All right, well Justin, that sounds
fantastic, and I know I'm looking

35
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:55.350
forward to it and it sounds like
that you might be interested in.

36
00:01:55.350 --> 00:01:58.278
>> Well, we look forward to seeing
you in the upcoming series.

37
00:01:58.278 --> 00:02:03.219
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin show you how to build a standard TCP socket connection using Python. Here they walk you through the Python documentation looking at necessary pieces to make up a socket that will connect to a given host address and port number, after which it will verify the connection by displaying a code to the screen.
episodes.title: Create a Socket Connection

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin demonstrate using Python to create a simple port scanner. Here they will build upon their socket connection to query a machine on specified ports. They also look at debugging errors.
episodes.title: Create a Port Scanner

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin create a Python program that will make a socket connection to an open port and then grab banner info for enumeration purposes. They also bundle this banner grabbing feature with the port scanner from the previous episode so that you can scan and banner grab the discovered open ports in one fell swoop.
episodes.title: Banner Reading from Open Ports

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin use the power of Python to build a brute-force program that attacks SSH for the purpose of testing weak passwords. Here they spend the majority of the time programming the SSH connection portion with a little help from Paramiko.
episodes.title: Brute Forcing an SSH Connection

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin continue building their SSH brute-force program. Here they build the brute-force portion of the program, puts it together with the SSH connect program, and then attacks an SSH server to test for weak passwords.
episodes.title: Brute Forcing an SSH Connection Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin build a TCP packet sniffer with Python. Here they will show you how to make the correct socket connection, explain the security permissions surrounding packet capture, create an infinite loop to capture more than one packet, discuss capture output, and look at doing this in Python 2 vs 3.
episodes.title: Packet Sniffing with Python

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin start a new project that will use Python to help us format our RAW packet data into a readable .pcap file. Here you'll see how to format the data and then send that data to a .pcap file which you can then view using a standard tool like Wireshark or TCPdump.
episodes.title: Packet Capture Output

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin build a new project that connects with their sniffer program to unpack the TCP packet and extract the Ethernet Frames. They will then take that extracted Frame, grab the MAC address, and print it to the screen in real time.
episodes.title: Ethernet Frames from RAW Packets

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin build a new project that connects with their MAC grabbing program to unpack the IP Headers from the Ethernet Frames. They will then take those IP headers and print them to the screen in real time.
episodes.title: IP Headers from Ethernet Frames

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin build upon their Sniffer program to make it extract only TCP segments from the RAW TCP data and then have that printed to the screen.
episodes.title: TCP Segments

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin build upon their Sniffer program to make it extract only UDP segments from the RAW data and then have that printed to the screen.
episodes.title: UDP Segments

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin employ Python to create a rudimentary, single connection server. Here you'll see how to build the server module which will open a port and accept incoming client connections and receive data from said client.
episodes.title: Creating a TCP Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin take many of the projects that they've been building and throw them all together into an amalgamation they call the Forwarding Packet Sniffer.
episodes.title: Forwarding Packet Sniffer
